author: We love Budapest
title: Here's what Budapest's new main square will look like
text:
It's always a win when public spaces go greener – especially when it means more room for relaxation and recreation for us. Whether you're a local or just visiting, you'll soon be able to enjoy a brand-new community space in the heart of the city, just steps away from Deák Ferenc tér. The transformation of Városháza Park, located in front of City Hall, was first announced by the City of Budapest in 2021. If all goes to plan, work will begin next year, with plenty of exciting changes and innovations to improve the area's climate and overall livability.
Once a private parking lot, the space is set to become Budapest's new main square. Last summer, a pop-up park already gave a taste of what's to come, offering a glimpse into the vision created by Lépték-Terv Landscape Architecture Firm. The full transformation is expected to be completed by 2026, delivering a vibrant new community space to the city.
Here, the city's new, very green and super cool main square is being created, finally freeing City Hall's 3rd courtyard from its confinement. This space might easily become a central meeting point in the heart of Budapest, in an area where the amount of green space per person is currently the lowest. The conceptual plans for Városháza Park are now complete – wrote Mayor Gergely Karácsony on his Facebook page.
Itt készül a város új, nagyon zöld és nagyon menő főtere, ami felszabadítja végre a Városháza 3-as udvarát a...
Közzétette:[Karácsony Gergely]–[2025. január 19., vasárnap]
The redesign features smart, eco-friendly solutions to help cool the area rather than trap heat. Green space will increase by 50%, rainwater will be collected for watering plants, and a lush green wall will be added to the City Hall façade.
(Cover photo: City of Budapest)

author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Family tracked stolen luggage to thief’s house using Apple AirTag
text:
Summary by Ground News The Gavino family of South Carolina was on their way to enjoy the North Carolina mountains when one of their bags never arrived at their destination. Apple AirTags are small trackers that can be attached to personal items and tracked on an Apple device. When their bag never arrived on the baggage carousel on 22 December, she tracked the AirTag and discovered it was on its way to a nearby residential area. Share menu More

author: KSBW via CNN Newsource
title: Missing hiker found alive after being lost for 10 days in mountains
text: SANTA CRUZ COUNTY, Calif. (KSBW) - A missing hiker was finally rescued after he was lost for 10 days in the Santa Cruz Mountains of California.The 34-year-old man was only going for a three-hour hike when he disappeared.“I didn’t bring anything because I thought I was doing a three-hour hike to go to work,” Lukas McClish, the rescued hiker, said.He was lost in the woods for nine nights and 10 days, shirtless with only a flashlight and folding scissors.It would be more than a week before the raggedy-looking hiker would be found.“So, I kind of just hiked. Each day, I go up a canyon, down a canyon to the next waterfall, sit down by the waterfall, drink water out of my boot,” Lukas McClish recalled.It was a Tuesday when Lukas McClish went for a hike in Boulder Creek and ended up getting lost.“I felt comfortable the whole time I was out there. I wasn’t worried about it,” Lukas McClish said. “I had a mountain lion that was following me, but it was cool. It kept its distances. I think it was just somebody watching over me.”The problem was that Lukas McClish didn’t tell anyone where he was going.By the time Father’s Day rolled around on Sunday, his family started worrying and filed a missing person’s report.The search was on then.“Some nights, although, I just had to trust God that he was going to be OK, and that was hard to do some nights when we would go to bed at night because I would worry about where he was, where he was sleeping and how cold he was and where he was if he was alive,” Diane McClish, the hiker’s mother, said.Lukas McClish drank from water from creeks, ate wild berries and slept on a wet bed of leaves all while yelling for help and thinking of his next meal.“‘Just help. Help, I’m over here.’ Or, ‘Is anybody out there?’” Lukas McClish remembered saying while he was lost. “I want a burrito or a taco bowl. That’s what I thought about every day when I, after the first five days, when I started to kind of realize that I might be in over my head.”But on Thursday afternoon, someone finally heard his cries for help.The Boulder Creek Fire Department deployed a drone and spotted his location.A K-9 tracked him down and Lukas McClish was escorted out of a remote canyon, finally reunited with family.“Met a lot of people because I had more people come to me and tell me how much they love my son and how they just hoped that we would find him,” Diane McClish said. “I didn’t realize that so many people in this town love Luke.”Fortunately, Lukas McClish had no major injuries. Copyright 2024 KSBW via CNN Newsource. All rights reserved.

title: 为海洋事业提供科技助力（编辑手记） --经济·科技--人民网
text:
为海洋事业提供科技助力（编辑手记）
2025年04月03日05:56 | 来源：
人民网－人民日报
小字号
研发中空纤维反渗透膜，建成国内首条反渗透复合膜生产线，研制海水淡化工程应用的反渗透组件……50余年来，高从堦院士围绕海水淡化技术不断攻关，推动我国海水淡化技术从无到有、从实验室走向工程应用，为海洋事业提供坚强助力。
海水淡化能有效解决淡水资源短缺、实现水资源利用的开源增量，在促进农业工业用水、助力远洋渔业发展方面发挥重要作用。在国家重大需求面前，高从堦不畏艰难、奋力创新，打破技术壁垒、推动降本应用，提高了我国海水淡化技术的核心竞争力。
对高从堦来说，海洋充满神秘与挑战，孜孜以求的动力源自他独到的眼光和浓浓的家国情怀。逐梦深蓝、提高海洋资源开发能力，为我国海洋事业发展不断奔走，相信在更多如高从堦一样的科研工作者共同努力下，我国的海洋科技领域必将涌现更多成果。
《 人民日报 》（ 2025年04月03日 06 版）
(责编：赵欣悦、袁勃)
关注公众号：人民网财经

author: newsdesk@nottinghampost.com (Neil Shaw)
title: Drivers warned visibility will be down by up to 60% until January 3
text:
Drivers have been warned that fireworks are a driving hazard and can cut visibility by over half. As New Year’s Eve approaches, motoring experts at
LeaseCar.uk have advised motorists to avoid driving during firework displays.
Although enjoyed during New Year celebrations, fireworks can affect short-term air quality and lead to a significant reduction in visibility which is a hazard for all road users. Using data from meteorological stations throughout the UK, scientists found that on average visibility is reduced by a quarter when there are fireworks.
In some parts of the UK, significantly higher visibility reductions have been recorded, including 64% in Nottingham. The visibility-reducing effects can last for up to two days after a fireworks display, meaning drivers should be extra cautious until at least January 3.
The reduction in visibility is caused by atmospheric particulate matter from fireworks which is scattered after detonation. If humidity is high, the effects can be even worse because the particles can scatter light more effectively.
Motorists who are unable to avoid driving during the New Year celebrations must take extra precautions to stay safe including lowering speeds. The Highway Code also states that motorists must use headlights when visibility is seriously reduced, and that they can use front or rear fog lights until it improves.
Other tips for driving in low-visibility conditions include braking slower to give drivers behind more time to slow down and listening for other vehicles before changing lanes. Tim Alcock from
LeaseCar.uk said: “Many motorists will be shocked to find out that fireworks can dramatically cut visibility on the roads.
“Although firework displays can be distracting, the majority of drivers know the importance of keeping their eyes on the road. However, it is not common knowledge that fireworks can affect air quality which has visibility-reducing consequences which are dangerous for all road users.
“On average, fireworks displays cut visibility by a quarter, but in some parts of the UK, it has been recorded at over 60 per cent. This is a real concern for motorists heading out over the New Year period, and for the days after, because their chances of getting involved in a car crash are increased.
“It is important that motorists alter their driving style if they know firework displays are on because there is evidence to suggest it will lower visibility, even if you don’t see a difference.
“Use headlights, reduce speeds and brake slower on the day, and the days that follow a big display, to avoid getting into an accident.”
